item.title: Sub-picosecond topological phase transition in nonlinear exciton–polariton superlattices
item.author: Hefei ZhaoZheng GuanWenjing Liu
item.content:encoded:
Achieving versatile, tunable, real-time topological photonic system is challenging. Now this is accomplished by designing superlattices of WS2 and a polymer embedded in a microcavity.

Hefei ZhaoZheng GuanWenjing Liu

Nature Physics

item.title: Low-overhead transversal fault tolerance for universal quantum computation
item.author: Hengyun ZhouChen ZhaoMikhail D. Lukin
item.content:encoded:
Logical operations can be performed fault-tolerantly with only a constant number of syndrome extraction rounds for a broad class of quantum error correction codes, including the surface code with magic state inputs and feedforward, to achieve ‘transversal algorithmic fault tolerance’.

Hengyun ZhouChen ZhaoMikhail D. Lukin

Nature

item.title: A tweezer array with 6100 highly coherent atomic qubits
item.author: Hannah J. ManetschGyohei NomuraManuel Endres
item.content:encoded:
Hannah J. ManetschGyohei NomuraManuel Endres

Nature

item.title: Industry-compatible silicon spin-qubit unit cells exceeding 99% fidelity
item.author: Paul SteinackerNard Dumoulin StuyckAndrew S. Dzurak
item.content:encoded:
Two-qubit operations exceeding 99% fidelity have been demonstrated by silicon devices made with standard semiconductor tooling in a 300-mm foundry environment.

Paul SteinackerNard Dumoulin StuyckAndrew S. Dzurak

Nature

item.title: Chip-scale electrically driven superconducting coherent photon sources for quantum information processing
item.author: Kaveh Delfanazari
item.content:encoded:
This Review highlights chip-scale superconducting coherent photon source technologies and their rich potential as an important integrated quantum hardware to advance quantum information processing and communication networks.

Kaveh Delfanazari

Nature Photonics

item.title: Daily briefing: World’s first AI-designed viruses attack antibiotic-resistant bacteria
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
Scientists have used Evo1 and Evo2 to design novel genomes for viruses capable of killing E. coli. Plus, a federal research funding is trickling back into Harvard and what drove the rise of complex societies.

Flora Graham

Nature

item.title: Atomic ‘conveyor belt’ boosts power of quantum computer
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
Array system could help to scale up technology that uses atoms to create qubits.

Davide Castelvecchi

Nature

item.title: Acoustic phonon phase gates with number-resolving phonon detection
item.author: Hong QiaoZhaoyou WangAndrew N. Cleland
item.content:encoded:
It has been proposed that phonons propagating through a material can be used for quantum computing, in a similar manner to photons. Now, several of the quantum gates and measurements needed for this approach have been demonstrated.

Hong QiaoZhaoyou WangAndrew N. Cleland

Nature Physics

item.title: Constant-overhead magic state distillation
item.author: Adam WillsMin-Hsiu HsiehHayata Yamasaki
item.content:encoded:
The creation and purification of magic states can be a limiting step in quantum computing. Now an error correcting code has been found where the overhead of this process is the lowest value possible, showing that optimal performance can be achieved.

Adam WillsMin-Hsiu HsiehHayata Yamasaki

Nature Physics

item.title: Topological microwave isolator with >100-dB isolation
item.author: Gang WangLing Lu
item.content:encoded:
Although typical microwave isolators provide 20 dB of isolation, a topological isolator—based on a one-way edge waveguide—enables 100 dB isolation due to the near-complete absorption of the backward-propagating mode. In theory, 200 dB of isolation is possible within a single-wavelength-size device.

Gang WangLing Lu

Nature Photonics

item.title: Continuous operation of a coherent 3,000-qubit system
item.author: Neng-Chun ChiuElias C. TrappMikhail D. Lukin
item.content:encoded:
Neng-Chun ChiuElias C. TrappMikhail D. Lukin

Nature

item.title: Weird ‘time crystals’ are made visible at last
item.author: Elizabeth Gibney
item.content:encoded:
Time crystals, a state of matter once thought physically impossible, could soon be on a banknote.

Elizabeth Gibney

Nature

item.title: Publisher Correction: Experimental determination of partial charges with electron diffraction
item.author: Soheil MahmoudiTim GrueneBernhard K. Keppler
item.content:encoded:
Soheil MahmoudiTim GrueneBernhard K. Keppler

Nature

item.title: Parallelized telecom quantum networking with an ytterbium-171 atom array
item.author: Lintao LiXiye HuJacob P. Covey
item.content:encoded:
Most atom-based quantum networks emit photons at non-telecom wavelengths, requiring lossy conversion for long-distance links. A scalable approach for generating direct entanglement between atoms and telecom-band photons has now been demonstrated.

Lintao LiXiye HuJacob P. Covey

Nature Physics

item.title: Electrically triggered spin–photon devices in silicon
item.author: Michael DobinsonCamille BownessDaniel B. Higginbottom
item.content:encoded:
Two types of on-chip silicon device utilizing silicon T centres are developed: an O-band light-emitting diode and an electrically triggered single-photon source. Further, a new method of spin initialization with electrical excitation is demonstrated.

Michael DobinsonCamille BownessDaniel B. Higginbottom

Nature Photonics

item.title: Probing the Kitaev honeycomb model on a neutral-atom quantum computer
item.author: Simon J. EveredMarcin KalinowskiMikhail D. Lukin
item.content:encoded:
Digital quantum simulations of Kitaev’s honeycomb model are realized for two-dimensional fermionic systems using a reconfigurable atom-array processor and used to study the Fermi–Hubbard model on a square lattice.

Simon J. EveredMarcin KalinowskiMikhail D. Lukin

Nature

item.title: Probing non-equilibrium topological order on a quantum processor
item.author: M. WillT. A. CochranF. Pollmann
item.content:encoded:
A superconducting quantum computer is used to realize an out-of-equilibrium topologically ordered state, which hosts anyonic excitations.

M. WillT. A. CochranF. Pollmann

Nature

item.title: Amplifying antigen-induced cellular responses with proximity labelling
item.author: Shuojun LiYinghui MenShuo Han
item.content:encoded:
Red light- or ultrasound-controlled proximity labelling is engineered to stimulate clustering-induced receptor activation and downstream signalling amplification to promote antitumour immune responses.

Shuojun LiYinghui MenShuo Han

Nature

item.title: Stabilizing effect of amino acids on protein and colloidal dispersions
item.author: Ting MaoXufeng XuFrancesco Stellacci
item.content:encoded:
Amino acids possess a new and broad colloidal property: they stabilize patchy nanoscale colloids, such as proteins, by adsorbing onto their surfaces through weak interactions.

Ting MaoXufeng XuFrancesco Stellacci

Nature

item.title: Certifying almost all quantum states with few single-qubit measurements
item.author: Hsin-Yuan HuangJohn PreskillMehdi Soleimanifar
item.content:encoded:
The certification protocol presented here is an efficient way to verify that a many-qubit quantum state is close to a desired target state. As well as enabling the verification of near-term quantum devices, it has applications to quantum learning.

Hsin-Yuan HuangJohn PreskillMehdi Soleimanifar

Nature Physics

item.title: Photons learn to classify with a quantum edge
item.author: Nicholas HarrisDarius Bunandar
item.content:encoded:
The quantum nature of light has been harnessed in a photonic chip to perform machine-learning tasks. For specifically designed problems, the approach outperforms established classical methods.

Nicholas HarrisDarius Bunandar

Nature Photonics

item.title: Taming photons on a chip
item.author: Xiangyu HuangNa Liu
item.content:encoded:
The integration of a quantum emitter-embedded metasurface (QEMS) with a microelectromechanical system (MEMS)-actuated cavity enables ångstrom-level wavelength tuning and dynamic polarization-resolved emission. The platform provides a design paradigm for reconfigurable solid-state photon sources.

Xiangyu HuangNa Liu

Nature Photonics

item.title: 3D-printed micro ion trap technology for quantum information applications
item.author: Shuqi XuXiaoxing XiaHartmut Häffner
item.content:encoded:
High-resolution 3D printing technology making use of two-photon polymerization instead of traditional machining is described, allowing low-cost and scalable production of large arrays of high-quality 3D Paul traps.

Shuqi XuXiaoxing XiaHartmut Häffner

Nature

item.title: Training of physical neural networks
item.author: Ali MomeniBabak RahmaniRomain Fleury
item.content:encoded:
Methods to train physical neural networks, such as backpropagation-based and backpropagation-free approaches, are explored to allow scaling up of artificial intelligence models far beyond present small-scale laboratory demonstrations, potentially enhancing computational efficiency.

Ali MomeniBabak RahmaniRomain Fleury

Nature

item.title: These ‘glass straw’ optical fibres could speed up the Internet
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
A cable design that sends light through air, rather than solid glass, could cut signal loss and make long-distance transmissions cheaper.

Davide Castelvecchi

Nature

item.title: Daily briefing: Epigenetic atlas shows how ageing tweaks DNA
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
Researchers paint the most comprehensive picture to date of how ageing modifies our genes. Plus, a new type of optical fibre and why scientists are flocking to Substack.

Flora Graham

Nature

item.title: Topological prethermal strong zero modes on superconducting processors
item.author: Feitong JinSi JiangDong-Ling Deng
item.content:encoded:
Stable and robust topological edge modes are observed at finite temperatures in an array of 100 programmable superconducting qubits because of emergent symmetries present in the prethermal regime of this system.

Feitong JinSi JiangDong-Ling Deng

Nature

item.title: Realization of an untrusted intermediate relay architecture using a quantum dot single-photon source
item.author: Mi ZouYu-Ming HeJian-Wei Pan
item.content:encoded:
Quantum information cannot be copied, posing challenges for long-distance communication due to signal losses. Here the quantum relay architecture using a single-photon source enhances the signal-to-noise ratio of quantum information transmission.

Mi ZouYu-Ming HeJian-Wei Pan

Nature Physics

item.title: Einstein hated entanglement — and five other quantum myths
item.author: Maria ViolarisEstelle InackEmily Adlam
item.content:encoded:
There’s nothing intuitive about quantum theory — six physicists debunk some of the most common misconceptions.

Maria ViolarisEstelle InackEmily Adlam

Nature

item.title: Daily briefing: Repeated heatwaves make your biological clock run fast
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
Repeated heatwaves can age you as much as smoking or drinking alcohol. Plus, a US Supreme Court ruling has derailed researchers’ efforts to reinstate cancelled research grants and six quantum myths debunked.

Flora Graham

Nature

item.title: Magnon-polarons in the Fermi–Hubbard model
item.author: Max L. PrichardZengli BaWaseem S. Bakr
item.content:encoded:
In strongly correlated systems, how magnetic excitations are renormalized by charge carriers remains an open question. An experiment now reports the observation of magnon-polarons—magnons dressed by doped holes—in a Fermi–Hubbard quantum simulator.

Max L. PrichardZengli BaWaseem S. Bakr

Nature Physics

item.title: Universal quantum gate set for Gottesman–Kitaev–Preskill logical qubits
item.author: V. G. MatsosC. H. ValahuT. R. Tan
item.content:encoded:
There are many quantum systems that act as high-quality quantum harmonic oscillators, and they can be used to store quantum information using the Gottesman–Kitaev–Preskill code. Entangling gates have now been demonstrated between two of these qubits.

V. G. MatsosC. H. ValahuT. R. Tan

Nature Physics

item.title: Quantum logic with bosonic error correction
item.author: Zhubing Jia
item.content:encoded:
The most commonly pursued quantum error-correction schemes encode quantum information using multiple two-level qubits. Now, two logical qubits have been encoded in the infinite-dimensional bosonic motional degrees of freedom of a trapped ion.

Zhubing Jia

Nature Physics

item.title: Extended native gate sets to unlock the performance of quantum processors
item.author: N/A
item.content:encoded:
Quantum operations are modelled as unitary matrices, yet experimental implementations have been restricted to only a few gate types. This fundamental limitation has now been overcome using a scheme that combines frequency control with microwave driving, enabling universal implementation of arbitrary two-qubit operations.

Nature Physics

item.title: A fluorescent-protein spin qubit
item.author: Jacob S. FederBenjamin S. SolowayPeter C. Maurer
item.content:encoded:
An optically addressable fluorescent-protein spin qubit is realized using enhanced yellow fluorescent protein; the qubit can be coherently controlled at liquid-nitrogen temperatures and the spin detected at room temperature in cells.

Jacob S. FederBenjamin S. SolowayPeter C. Maurer

Nature

item.title: Realization of a doped quantum antiferromagnet in a Rydberg tweezer array
item.author: Mu QiaoGabriel EmperaugerAntoine Browaeys
item.content:encoded:
A doped quantum antiferromagnet is obtained by using a Rydberg tweezer array comprising three levels encoding spins and holes to implement a tunable model that allows the study of previously inaccessible parameter regimes.

Mu QiaoGabriel EmperaugerAntoine Browaeys

Nature

item.title: Proximity screening greatly enhances electronic quality of graphene
item.author: Daniil DomaretskiyZefei WuAndre K. Geim
item.content:encoded:
Screening by a graphite gate placed at 1 nm proximity to graphene produces transformative improvement in its electronic quality, reducing charge inhomogeneity by two orders of magnitude.

Daniil DomaretskiyZefei WuAndre K. Geim

Nature

item.title: Optical signatures of interlayer electron coherence in a bilayer semiconductor
item.author: Xiaoling LiuNadine LeisgangMikhail D. Lukin
item.content:encoded:
Condensates of excitons have been observed in the quantum Hall regime, but evidence for their existence at low magnetic fields remains controversial. Now evidence of coherence between optically pumped interlayer excitons in MoS2 marks a step towards confirming exciton condensation at low magnetic fields.

Xiaoling LiuNadine LeisgangMikhail D. Lukin

Nature Physics

item.title: Electrochemical loading enhances deuterium fusion rates in a metal target
item.author: Kuo-Yi ChenJannis MaiwaldCurtis P. Berlinguette
item.content:encoded:
A benchtop fusion reactor, called the Thunderbird Reactor, is described, showing that electrochemically loading a metal lattice with deuterium could enhance nuclear fusion rates when that metal is also bombarded by deuterium ions.

Kuo-Yi ChenJannis MaiwaldCurtis P. Berlinguette

Nature

item.title: Experimental determination of partial charges with electron diffraction
item.author: Soheil MahmoudiTim GrueneBernhard K. Keppler
item.content:encoded:
An experimental method is used to assign partial charges based on crystal structure determination through electron diffraction, applicable to any crystalline compound.

Soheil MahmoudiTim GrueneBernhard K. Keppler

Nature

item.title: Daily briefing: Why fertility rates are declining — and what to do about it
item.author: Flora Graham
item.content:encoded:
What’s behind steep population declines in most countries. Plus, microbes fine-tune the flavour of chocolate and a quantum ‘brain’ designed with the help of artificial intelligence.

Flora Graham

Nature

item.title: Coherent control of magnon–polaritons using an exceptional point
item.author: N. J. LambertA. SchumerH. G. L. Schwefel
item.content:encoded:
Deterministic control of the gain–loss balance in non-Hermitian systems remains challenging. A magnonic hybrid platform is now shown to enable this and, hence, coherently control excitations by leveraging an exceptional point.

N. J. LambertA. SchumerH. G. L. Schwefel

Nature Physics

item.title: Efficient implementation of arbitrary two-qubit gates using unified control
item.author: Zhen ChenWeiyang LiuFei Yan
item.content:encoded:
The efficiency of a quantum computer depends on which basic operations it can implement. Now a scheme that can implement any two-qubit logic gate has been demonstrated on a superconducting architecture.

Zhen ChenWeiyang LiuFei Yan

Nature Physics

item.title: AI helps assemble ‘brain’ of future quantum computer
item.author: Jenna Ahart
item.content:encoded:
As a demonstration, artificial-intelligence system helps to make a miniature, high-speed animation of physicists’ favourite feline.

Jenna Ahart

Nature

item.title: Entanglement and the density matrix renormalization group in the generalized Landau paradigm
item.author: Laurens LootensClement DelcampFrank Verstraete
item.content:encoded:
Quantum spin chains can be represented in several ways, and eigenstates in these dual models have different entanglement structures. By characterizing the dual theories, the optimal tensor network algorithm for simulating the models has been found.

Laurens LootensClement DelcampFrank Verstraete

Nature Physics

item.title: Controversial quantum-computing paper gets hefty correction — but concerns linger
item.author: Dan Garisto
item.content:encoded:
The journal Science has lifted an expression of concern on a paper claiming evidence of Majorana quasiparticles and added new details.

Dan Garisto

Nature

item.title: A mechanical quantum memory for microwave photons
item.author: Alkım B. BozkurtOmid GolamiMohammad Mirhosseini
item.content:encoded:
Superconducting qubits, a leading platform for quantum information processing, suffer from decoherence. Interfacing them with nanomechanical oscillators allows quantum information to be stored in motional states with longer lifetimes.

Alkım B. BozkurtOmid GolamiMohammad Mirhosseini

Nature Physics

item.title: Is gravity quantum? Experiments could finally probe one of physics’ biggest questions
item.author: Davide Castelvecchi
item.content:encoded:
Physicists are developing laboratory tests to give insight into the true nature of gravity.

Davide Castelvecchi

Nature

item.title: How to twist anyons
item.author: Matteo CarregaStefan Heun
item.content:encoded:
The properties of quantum Hall states can be probed in experiments inspired by optical interferometers. Now, a device design that overcomes major drawbacks of existing interferometers allows the extraction of the quasiparticle statistics.

Matteo CarregaStefan Heun

Nature Physics

item.title: Trump’s chief science adviser faces a storm of criticism: what's next?
item.author: Jeff Tollefson
item.content:encoded:
US researchers were hopeful when Donald Trump appointed Michael Kratsios to a top science position, but many say he has contributed to the chaos. Can he turn things around?

Jeff Tollefson

Nature
